data.title: Tiara of the month: how Queen Maud’s glittering diadem was stolen during a jewellery heist in London and never recovered
data.meta_description: The headpiece was thought to have been created by the jewellers Carrington and Co in 1896 in time to be worn by Princess Maud of Wales at her wedding to Prince Carl of Denmark
data.text:
Surrounding this exquisite piece of royal regalia, there exists a tale that sparkles with intrigue. A

diamond and pearl tiara sits at the centre of a crime never to have been solved. The towering

diadem is Edwardian in style featuring a delicate diamond scroll motif and pear shaped pearl toppers and is transformable into a low-lying version.

It is believed to have been created by the jewellers Carrington and Co in 1896 in time to be worn by Princess Maud of Wales at her wedding to Prince Carl of Denmark. Maud was the fifth child of Albert and Alexandra, Prince and Princess of Wales, who would soon ascend the British throne upon the death of Albert’s mother, Queen Victoria in 1901.

When the union of 1814 between Norway and Sweden was dissolved it triggered the decision to invite Carl and Maud to be the new King and Queen of Norway, he was subsequently renamed and crowned a year later in 1906 as King Haakon VII. Throughout her reign, Queen Maud split her time between England and Norway, often being spotted wearing her precious pearl tiara at state events showcasing her covetable sense of style.

It was possibly due to the impending war that Maud had brought much of her jewellery collection with her from Norway upon a stay in 1938, when, following an operation she unexpectedly passed away. For the following fifteen years, the Norwegian jewellery was held safely in the UK only to be amicably reclaimed following the family’s attendance at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953.

Maud’s grandson, the current King Harald V of Norway and his wife Sonja, ascended the throne in 1991. As firm fans of Maud’s tiara, they sent it to London for refurbishing by renowned British

jewellers Garrard in 1995, only for it to be stolen during a planned heist involving three armed robbers.

Nearly 70 police officers were immediately assigned to the premises but to no avail, the tiara was among the thieved items and has never been found. Of course, the House of Garrard, creators of the most significant British regal treasures, crafted a perfect replica to present to the family.
